steps.title: Keeping the scab moist with a warm compress can help it heal faster.
steps.content: Keeping the scab moist with a warm compress can help it heal faster. Wet a clean cloth or towel with warm water. Then, place it on the scab for five to ten minutes. Do this several times a day to keep the scab moist.

steps.title: Epsom salts are great for healing and reducing tenderness around the scab.
steps.content: Epsom salts are great for healing and reducing tenderness around the scab. Fill a bucket or the bath with warm water and ¼ cup Epsom salts. Then, soak the injured area with the scab in the salt bath for an hour. Pat the area dry. [1] X Research source Soak the scab once to twice a day until it starts to heal.

steps.title: A non-stick dressing on the scab helps keep it clean.
steps.content: A non-stick dressing on the scab helps keep it clean. Apply petroleum jelly under the dressing to encourage healing.

steps.title: Petroleum jelly is a good way to keep the scab moist and keep any bacteria out.
steps.content: Petroleum jelly is a good way to keep the scab moist and keep any bacteria out. The moisture will help the scab to soften and allow new skin to grow over the scab, healing the wound and the scab. Dab a small amount of petroleum jelly on the scab throughout the day to keep it moist. Over a few days, it should soften and fade away or peel off on its own.

steps.title: Honey contains antibacterial properties and can speed up healing.
steps.content: Honey contains antibacterial properties and can speed up healing. Put a small amount of medical-grade honey on the scab to help it heal faster. You can find medical-grade honey online or at your local drugstore.

steps.title: Tea tree oil is a great natural oil for treating scabs.
steps.content: Tea tree oil is a great natural oil for treating scabs. It can speed up the healing process and prevent the scab from leaving a scar. Apply tea tree oil to the scab once to twice a day. [2] X Research source You can find tea tree oil at your local health food store or online.

steps.title: Garlic is antibacterial and antiseptic, so it’s a good natural way to heal a scab.
steps.content: Garlic is antibacterial and antiseptic, so it’s a good natural way to heal a scab. Blend or mix two to three cloves of garlic with one cup of wine. Then, let the mixture sit for two to three hours. Apply the mixture to the scab with a cotton ball. [3] X Research source Rinse the garlic wine mixture off after 10-15 minutes with warm water. If the garlic causes your skin to itch, remove it right away.

steps.title: Onion contains antibacterial properties.
steps.content: Onion contains antibacterial properties. It is good at healing wounds and scabs as well as preventing infection. Chop up the onion and make a paste with honey. Then, apply the paste to the scab and let it sit for 10-15 minutes. Rinse the paste off with warm water. [4] X Research source You can apply the onion honey paste up to four times a day.

steps.title: Baking soda is a mild antiseptic and good for removing scabs.
steps.content: Baking soda is a mild antiseptic and good for removing scabs. Mix 10 grams (0.35 oz) of baking soda with 100 milliliters (3.4 fl oz) water to make a paste. Then, apply the paste over the scab. Let it sit for 10-15 minutes and then wash it off with warm water. [5] X Research source You can apply the baking soda paste two to three times a week.

steps.title: Aloe vera is a great natural substance that can help speed up healing.
steps.content: Aloe vera is a great natural substance that can help speed up healing. Put aloe vera on the scab and let it sit for five minutes. Then, rinse it off with warm water. Do this three to four times a day. [6] X Research source You can find aloe vera in gel form online or at your local health store. If you have access to an aloe vera plant, you can squeeze the juice from the plant onto the scab.

steps.title: Leaving the scab open to the air will help it heal.
steps.content: Leaving the scab open to the air will help it heal. You don’t want to keep it too moist, as this can allow a fungal infection to take hold. Alternate treating the scab with ointment and allowing it to dry.

steps.title: A new scab will likely develop in its place and the wound will take longer to heal.
steps.content: A new scab will likely develop in its place and the wound will take longer to heal. Picking off the scab can increase the risk of infection, cause scarring, and prolong the healing time for the wound. Avoid the temptation to pick off the scab to get rid of it.

steps.title: Antiseptics can kill good bacteria on the scab and lead to swelling.
steps.content: Antiseptics can kill good bacteria on the scab and lead to swelling. Steer clear from hydrogen peroxide and iodine. [7] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source They can also dry out the scab, which can prolong the healing time for the scab. [8] X Research source [9] X Research source You can use topical antibiotic ointments like Neosporin on the scab.

steps.title: If the scab starts to swell, feels hot, or leaks pus or fluid, it may be infected.
steps.content: If the scab starts to swell, feels hot, or leaks pus or fluid, it may be infected. Go see a doctor right away so they can diagnose the issue and prescribe the right treatment. A scab that is infected and untreated can take a long time to heal or lead to other health issues. This is especially true in patients that have leg scars, as well as people that are diabetic or immunocompromised. Small scabs can lead to ulceration.
